news.headline: Omar Abdullah meets J&K Governor, demands statement from govt on Kashmir situation
news.content:
Omar Abdullah demanded the government to issue a statement that the people of Jammu and Kashmir do not need to be afraid. 
 Omar Abdullah said the Governor assured that no preparation is being made for any announcement.

news.headline: Parliament Session May be Extended Till August 9 as Govt Introduces Record Number of Bills
news.content:
Not enough time was given to us to even issue whip on the Triple Talaq Bill, said Anand Sharma, 
 Congress deputy leader in the Rajya Sabha, when asked about the five Congress MPs who were not present during voting on the legislation on Tuesday. 
 The opposition motion to send the Triple Talaq Bill to a select committee of Parliament for a larger discussion with stakeholders was defeated in the Upper House.

news.headline: Isro releases first set of earth pictures captured by Chandrayaan 2
news.content:
The Indian Space Research Organisation (Isro) on Sunday released the first set of images captured by Chandrayaan 2, 
 India s second lunar mission. The onboard camera captured pictures of Earth as viewed in space. ISRO said the images were taken by the LI4 
 camera on Vikram, the lander on Chandrayaan 2. The images were clicked on August 3, ISRO said. 
 Chandrayaan 2 is a Rs 978 crore project, with which India hopes to soft land a probe on Moon, while also put a satellite around its orbit.

news.headline: Parliament Session May be Extended Till August 9 as Govt Introduces Record Number of Bills
news.content:
Not enough time was given to us to even issue whip on the Triple Talaq Bill, said Anand Sharma, 
 Congress deputy leader in the Rajya Sabha, when asked about the five Congress MPs who were not present during voting on the legislation on Tuesday. 
 The opposition motion to send the Triple Talaq Bill to a select committee of Parliament for a larger discussion with stakeholders was defeated in the Upper House.

news.headline:
Chhichhore trailer: Sushant Singh Rajput, Shraddha Kapoor celebrate Friendship Day by retelling 3 Idiots,
 Dil Chahta Hai
news.content:
The trailer for Dangal director Nitesh Tiwari next, Chhichhore is out. Lead actors Sushant Singh Rajput and Shraddha Kapoor 
 shared the film trailer on social media on Friendship Day, Sunday. The film releases on August 30 
 and will clash with Prabhas and Shraddha starrer Saaho.

news.headline: Wouldnot be surprised if I go through ups and downs in my career again: Akshay Kumar
news.content:
Superstar Akshay Kumar has seen both good and bad phases in his career and he believes it is important 
 to learn from such experiences as nothing is permanent in life.The actor said he has seen people write an obituary of his career 
 after a string of flops but he has always made a strong comeback.

news.headline: On Kishore Kumars 90th birth anniversary, 10 lesser known facts about the maverick genius
news.content:
Born into a family of comfortable means, Kishores father Kunjalal Ganguly was employed as a personal lawyer 
 with a wealthy family of Khandwa, Madhya Pradesh. Born Abhas Kumar Ganguly in 1929, Kishore was the youngest of his four siblings including Ashok, Sati Devi and Anoop.
 When Kishore was still a child, his older brother Ashok ventured into films and became a big star in the Bombay film industry.

news.headline: Shah Rukh Khan to turn a Money Heist into a Bollywood film
news.content:
Money Heist revovles around an elusive criminal mastermind known as The Professor with a plan to pull off the biggest heist in history,
 by printing billions of euros in the Royal Mint of Spain. To help him, he recruits eight people with certain abilities who have nothing to lose.
 Season four of the hugely successful show is currently in production.

news.headline: Over 2 hours screen time daily will make your kids impulsive.
How to Know if You're Over-Managing Your Diabetes
news.content:
Experts say there is a balancing act of medication, insulin, and lifestyle changes that must be considered when drawing up a treatment plan.
 Some past research has indicated that the majority of people with type 2 diabetes aren’t being treated aggressively enough and aren’t seeing improvements in their blood sugar levels. 
 An appropriate treatment plan, explained McCoy, depends on a good relationship with the patient.

news.headline: Research shows how nordic walking may benefit breast cancer patients
news.content:
Nordic walking, an aerobic activity performed with walking poles similar to ski poles, may benefit patients with breast cancer, according to a review of existing research.
 The main strategy in rehabilitation for women with breast cancer is a change of habits, where physical exercise is a fundamental tool,said study co-author Jorge Torres of the Faculty of 
 Educational Sciences and Sports at the University of Vigo in Pontevedra, Spain.

news.headline: Kids with mild asthma can use inhalers when needed: Research
news.content:
A new research has found that kids with mild asthma can effectively manage the condition by using their two inhalers -- one a steroid 
 and the other a bronchodilator -- when symptoms occur.

news.headline: CCD founder: First victim of India's economic distress?
news.content:
The Coffee Day Enterprises founder VG Siddhartha, who had gone missing on Monday and his body was fished out a day later from the Netravati river, 
 might have been the first casualty of ongoing distress in the Indian economy. Siddhartha, according to the sources in the know, has taken a personal debt of Rs 500 crore to service the debt of companies he owned.
 The numbers of his Coffee Day Enterprises were not that convincing. So to keep credit lines going,Siddhartha had taken the personal loans, a friend of Siddhartha told DH.

news.headline: Bharti Airtel slips into red, posts Rs 2,866 crore loss in June Quarter
news.content:
Airtel had logged a net profit of Rs 97 crore in the same period of the previous year, the company said in a statement.The revenue of the 
 Sunil Mittal-led company rose 4.7 per cent to 
 Rs 20,738 crore during the first quarter ended June 2019 Rs 20,738 crore during the first quarter ended June 2019.

news.headline: Explained: Why Maruti Suzuki sales are dropping.
news.content:
Industry insiders feel that while the pressure on NBFC and liquidity squeeze in the market is a big factor,
 the decline in customer confidence is another factor that is leading to a continuous slide in sales of passenger cars.India biggest passenger car manufacturer 
 Maruti Suzuki announced a 36.2 per cent drop in passenger car sales in the month of July 2019.

news.headline: Tata Motors cuts Tigor EV price by up to Rs 80k
news.content:
Tata Motors on August 1 said it has decided to cut prices of Tigor EV by up to Rs 80,000 with immediate effect
 in order to pass the benefits of reduced GST on such models.The Tigor EV which was earlier priced between Rs 12.35-12.71 lakh (ex-showroom, Mumbai) will now be 
 available at a starting price of Rs 11.58-11.92 lakh, Chandra said.

news.headline: Astronomers are probing faraway planets with greater sophistication
news.content:
In the deluge of planets found beyond the solar system over the past decade, those of system toi-270 might not seem special.
 There are three of them, orbiting a star 73 light-years away. This is neither the closest system known, nor does it contain the most 
 Earthlike exoplanet. It has, though, sent a buzz through astronomy.

news.headline: New 3D map shows Milky Way is not shaped like pancake but a warped wave
news.content:
The new map, created by the University of Warsaw, was created by mapping over 2,400 cepheids that are scattered throughout the galaxy.
 Astronomers have charted a stellar three-dimensional map of the Milky Way that shows its disc of stars dramatically warped into a wave. 
The latest image once again proves that the spiral galaxy is not shaped like a flat disc.

news.headline: Asteroid danger: Neil deGrasse Tyson warns of harbinger of doom space rock threat
news.content:
ASTROPHYSICIST Neil deGrasse Tyson has warned of harbinger of doom asteroids threatening to wipe out all life on Earth.
Asteroids and meteors of all shapes and sizes fly past the Earth on a nearly daily basis. Space agency NASA estimates hundreds of tonnes of space debris and rocks
 safely pelt the planet atmosphere every single day. Larger, car-sized asteroids, are said to strike the Earth roughly once a year,
 causing small amounts of localised damage.The real threat comes from asteroids many miles wide, which astrophysicist Neil deGrasse Tyson
 said could spell an end for humanity.
